displayText.simplePara: Applies to AMPEL360 BWB-Q100 configuration (all LCNs) unless otherwise stated.

levelledPara.title: Overall Spar Configuration and Function
levelledPara.para: The forward wing spar is the primary front load-carrying member of the BWB-Q100 wing box. It runs continuously from butt line BL0 to the wing tip and, together with the aft spar, upper and lower covers, and ribs, forms the closed torque box.

Functions include: (1) providing continuous paths for bending and shear loads; (2) interfaces for control-surface hinge fittings and systems routing; and (3) sealed bays for fuel containment in applicable zones.

levelledPara.title: Load Paths and Structural Philosophy
levelledPara.para: Primary loads include upward bending from lift, torsion from control-surface activity, and local reactions (pylon, landing gear if installed). Axial tension/compression is carried mainly by spar caps; webs react shear.
Design philosophy is fail-safe and damage-tolerant with multiple load paths, crack-arrest features, and scheduled inspection access for condition-based maintenance.

levelledPara.title: Material Specifications
levelledPara.para: Spar caps: Al-Li alloy (e.g., AA2198-T8) or CFRP unidirectional laminates per configuration control.
Web panels: stiffened aluminum plate (e.g., AA2050-T84) or CFRP laminate with co-cured stringers; local doublers at cutouts and fittings.
Fittings/attachments: titanium or corrosion-resistant steel as required for bearing, galvanic compatibility, and fireworthiness.

levelledPara.title: Section Breakdown and Station Locations
levelledPara.para: The spar is partitioned into inboard, center, and outboard sections (FS-INB, FS-MID, FS-OUTB). Station numbering increases from the fuselage datum. Typical bay pitch is 380–520 mm inboard and 300–380 mm outboard; exact values per master geometry.

levelledPara.title: Interface Definitions
levelledPara.para: Wing covers attach via continuous cap splices and shear ties; wet bays use sealed faying surfaces. Systems route through reinforced web lightening holes with bonded grommets and chafe protection. Fire stops and shut-off valve hard points are provided inboard as required.

Quantum Sensorial Skin (QSS) installation: QSS is formed by Quantum Spare Sensors in a Quantum Superposition Setting. On the wing forward spar box these operate as a Quantum Spar Setting. The aim is to amplify weak structural signals or discretize continuous fields into quantized health states as needed. Mechanical interfaces include bonded carriers on webs/caps, shielded feed-throughs, and a local controller node. Event payloads produced by QSS inspections must conform to the Crack Event Schema.
